Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Story: I was sitting in the lifeguard chair, the sun beating down on my shoulders, when I remembered the text from Mom I hadn’t answered. She always wanted me to check in on weekends, just a quick message to let her know I was okay. I pulled out my phone, ready to type, but then I noticed the broken lane rope floating in the pool. Swim lessons would start in twenty minutes, and if the rope wasn’t fixed, the kids would be all over the place. My supervisor always reminded us to keep the equipment in perfect shape—no excuses. I glanced at my phone, feeling the weight of Mom’s expectation, her gentle reminders about staying in touch. But the pool was my responsibility too, and I could already hear the voices of the kids and their parents echoing in my mind if something went wrong. My fingers hovered over the screen, torn between sending a quick text and rushing to the storage room for the repair kit. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I felt stuck, unable to move, caught between being a good daughter and a responsible lifeguard.
